titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Simon Perchik Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:15

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, personal papers, photographs, printed material, and a videotaped interview, documenting the life and career of American poet Simon Perchik. Correspondence is chiefly professional in nature, consisting of letters from editors, publishers, and other authors, relating to the writings of Simon Perchik and to twentieth-century American poetry generally. Principal correspondents include Elizabeth Press and Edward Butscher. Writings consists of autograph manuscript and typescript drafts of Simon Perchik's poetry and prose, dating from the 1960s to the 1990s.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 14 (videocassettes): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Simon Perchik Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Simon Perchik Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Former call numbers: Uncat ZA MS 575, Uncat MSS 86

Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, in 2013. Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1947-1997. II. Writings, 1968-1998. III. Other Papers, 1942-1995. IV. Manuscript Material Removed from Books, 1979-1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, personal papers, photographs, printed material, and a videotaped interview, documenting the life and career of American poet Simon Perchik. Correspondence is chiefly professional in nature, consisting of letters from editors, publishers, and other authors, relating to the writings of Simon Perchik and to twentieth-century American poetry generally. Principal correspondents include Elizabeth Press and Edward Butscher. Writings consists of autograph manuscript and typescript drafts of Simon Perchik's poetry and prose, dating from the 1960s to the 1990s.

bioghist.head: Simon Perchik (1923-)
bioghist.p: Simon Perchik was born in Paterson, New Jersey, in 1923. After serving as a pilot in the Army Air Corps during the Second World War, he enrolled in New York University, where he received a B.A. in English and an L.L.B. in law. Perchik wrote poetry and practiced law from 1950 to 1980, after which he retired to write full-time. Among Perchik's published collections of poetry are I counted only April (New Rochelle, NY : Elizabeth Press, 1964) and Hands collected : the books of Simon Perchik : poems, 1949-1999 (Columbus, OH : Pavement Saw Press, 2000).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of professional correspondence with editors, publishers, and authors, relating to the writings of Simon Perchik; also includes some personal correspondence, chiefly with other writers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Writings of Simon Perchik and Writings of Others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of typescript and autograph manuscript drafts, unless otherwise indicated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title, with some unarranged material interfiled. This arrangement reflects the order in which the material was received by the library.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Other papers include clippings and other printed material, personal documents of Simon Perchik, and a videotaped interview with Simon Perchik.
The videotaped interview is stored in box 14 and is considered restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Box 14 (audiovisual material): Restricted fragile. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Correspondence and Notes, and Printed Material.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Many of Simon Perchik's books were received with this collection, and some books contained letters, notes, or printed material laid in. Series IV consists of papers that were removed from Simon Perchik's books after they were acquired by the library.

did.unittitle: Penney, Darby / The Snail's Pace Review
